Urticaria is a frequent inflammatory dermatosis (15-20% of the population in its acute form) secondary to the activation of masctocytes by complex immunological or non-immunological mechanisms. It is diagnosed clinically. The course of the disease is usually acute and sometimes chronic, with flare-ups occurring daily or almost daily for more than 6 weeks at a time.
Acute urticaria is usually non-allergic, although it may be allergic in rare cases.

question.title: What is the typical course of urticaria?

option_a.title: Acute and chronic, with flare-ups occurring daily for more than 6 weeks
option_a.description: A possible description of the course of urticaria

option_b.title: Chronic and rare, with flare-ups occurring only once a year
option_b.description: A plausible but incorrect description of the course of urticaria

option_c.title: Acute and non-allergic, with flare-ups occurring only at night
option_c.description: A plausible but incorrect description of the course of urticaria

option_d.title: Chronic and allergic, with flare-ups occurring only during stress
option_d.description: A plausible but incorrect description of the course of urticaria

correct_option.title: Acute and sometimes chronic, with flare-ups occurring daily or almost daily for more than 6 weeks
correct_option.description: The correct description of the course of urticaria
